soil_crop_relationships.subject: Sandy soils
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: Sandy soils retain less moisture and nutrients, and therefore, can be managed by providing water, organic matter, and fertilizers.

soil_crop_relationships.subject: Good soils
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: Similarly, crops such as banana do well on good soils

soil_crop_relationships.subject: Poor soils
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: while mango can grow on poor soils

management_practices.evidence: Sandy soils retain less moisture and nutrients, and therefore, can be managed by providing water, organic matter, and fertilizers.

soil_crop_relationships.subject: Soil nutrients (N, P, K)
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: Soil fertility mining in Uganda is among the highest in Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA), with an estimated average annual nutrient depletion of 70 kg of nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P) and potassium (K) (Stoorvogel and Smaling, 1990; Wortmann and Kaizzi, 1998).

management_practices.evidence: NARO and FAO (1999) estimate that smallholder farmers in Uganda apply an average of 1 kg of NPK/ha.
If inorganic fertilizer were used to restore the mined nutrients, it would cost an equivalent of a fifth of the farm income.

soil_crop_relationships.subject: soil pH
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: However, crop production depends on several interrelated agronomic factors, such as soil (e.g., pH, texture, organic matter content, water holding capacity, mineral composition, and nutrient availability, etc.), plant genetic material, crop management, and several other biotic and abiotic factors.

soil_crop_relationships.subject: soil nutrient availability
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: However, crop production depends on several interrelated agronomic factors, such as soil (e.g., pH, texture, organic matter content, water holding capacity, mineral composition, and nutrient availability, etc.), plant genetic material, crop management, and several other biotic and abiotic factors.

management_practices.evidence: Crop nutrition and balanced fertilization (both from inorganic and organic sources) are considered among the primary actions towards satisfactory crop growth and production while decreasing production costs.

management_practices.timing: since the end of World War II
management_practices.effect: prevented soil nutrient depletion and built-up soil fertility
management_practices.evidence: To increase crop yields, elevated levels of nitrogen (N), potassium (K), and phosphorus(P)-containing fertilizers as well as other macro and micronutrients have been applied in croplands since the end of World War II, have prevented soil nutrient depletion, and, in some cases, have even built-up soil fertility (maintenance fertility) [8].

soil_crop_relationships.subject: Umbrisol (Luyinjayinja)
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: Nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium were limiting nutrients for bean production in Umbrisol (Luyinjayinja)

soil_crop_relationships.subject: Cambisol (‘Limyufumyufu)
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: in Cambisol (‘Limyufumyufu), common bean production was most limited by soil acidity.

soil_crop_relationships.subject: Phaeozem (Liddugavu)
soil_crop_relationships.evidence: beans grown on the Phaeozem registering greater leaf number and growth, confirming both scientist’s and local farmer’s knowledge that this soil has greater potential than the other two soils.
